message.content:
cs.DC, cs.DS, cs.IT, cs.NI, cs.SY. 

The paper focuses on studying the computational resources required to solve problems in a single hop network where nodes communicate using only beeps. This falls under the category of distributed computing (cs.DC). The paper also discusses randomized leader election, which is a classic problem in distributed systems (cs.DS). The use of probabilistic transition precision and error bounds suggests that information theory (cs.IT) may be relevant. The fact that the communication is done using beeps implies that networking and internet architecture (cs.NI) may also be relevant. Finally, the paper discusses the simplicity threshold beyond which useful distributed computation is possible, which suggests that systems and control (cs.SY) may also be relevant.
